1. There is no smoking on UCHA property. This includes the HHH atrium, patio and all corridors in HHH and the A-Wing lounge. In addition, smoking is not permitted in all HHH public balconies (e.g., TV rooms, the lounge, study rooms and computer room) and in the passages leading up to the patio.

2. Members of UCHA residing not as students of UCLA but attending other non-UCLA accredited colleges or programs (example, UCLA Extension, EAP, visiting scholars, researches and the like, not receiving a qualified degree from UCLA), must fulfill one or more of the following requirements. All Non-UCLA students must be attending a college or university accredited by an agency recognized for academic accreditation purposes by the United States Department of Education: 
    a. Candidates working in summer internships may also be qualified for UCHA admission. Such applicants’ must be enrolled as Full-Time students and be engaged in work relevant to their field of study while in pursuit of such internships. Spaces offered may be for a limited number of students only and will be on a space availability basis. Eligibility will be determined by the ED. 
    b. Students other than UCLA students may continue as members only while pursuing a full-time degree (i.e., bachelors, Masters, PhD), Associate Degree, or certificate programs (no more than two certificates – exceptions must be approved by the BoD), and fulfilling the 12 unit requirement as stated above (see A.2.a). Students attending language schools or pursuing online courses of study are not eligible for UCHA membership/housing. Students of SMC or other accredited community colleges must be pursuing an Associate Degree and be enrolled in a full-time 12 semester/quarterly units course of study towards a bachelors degree each quarter of residence at the UCHA. Any exceptions would need to be approved by the ED or the BoD. If the said student has not obtained admission to a full-time bachelors program or professional degree, then he/she will no longer be eligible to reside as a member of the UCHA. Non-UCLA colleges include SMC, UCLA Extension, USC, California State University, or any other college as recognized by the United States Department of Education.

5. Once expelled for an offense other than R&B delinquency/chore deficiency, an individual must move out of the UCHA within 30 days, or by the end of the current quarter, if there is less than 30 days left. At its discretion the Membership Committee may reduce the period of time required to move out down from 30 days to as few as 3 days, of such an expulsion. If the co-oper is expelled for R&B delinquency/chore deficiency, the co-oper must move out of the UCHA within 7 days. Co-opers who have been expelled are still under contractual obligations. (BoD 9/7/00) 
    a. Any individual, once expelled, shall cease to enjoy the privileges of a member in good standing for the remainder of the time he/she is permitted to reside at UCHA. 
    b. The ED (Executive Director) is authorized, at his/her discretion, to impose a 3 day pay or quit notice on any member delinquent by a sum of $600.00 or more, after which the ED shall then start the eviction procedure. 
    c. If the R&B delinquent co-oper pays his/her account balance to within $50 before eviction proceeding have begun, then eviction proceedings will not be initiated. Once eviction notification has been provided, the co-oper will be billed for any costs incurred by the UCHA towards the eviction processes, as well as the eviction fee stated in rule. If the member wished to pay their account off after the eviction proceedings have begun, the approval of the ED shall be necessary. (BoD 3/2/00)

2. All co-opers checking into UCHA for the first time shall be assigned to one of three crews: kitchen, facilities, or kitchen cleaning. All new co-opers must remain on one of these 3 crews until the end of their first full quarter at UCHA or 12 consecutive chore shifts, after which they are eligible to work all other UCHA chore assignments. Exceptions to the above can be granted by the AMO. Priority shall be given to the kitchen crew, followed by the kitchen cleaning and facilities crews. Credit hours can be worked on any crew. 3. Members are admitted in the order listed below. Priority within each category is determined by date of application and deposit, seniority, and additional guidelines shall be set by the Board of Directors.  
    a. Members from the preceding regular academic quarter with valid contracts on file. The deadline for returning such new contracts shall be set by the ED but shall be no later than 60 days before the beginning of the upcoming quarter or other contract period. 
    b. Persons who were members from quarters other than the preceding regular quarter, provided that they still meet the academic status requirement for membership and provided that they apply prior to 60 days before the beginning of the appropriate quarter or summer session for which they wish to re-enter. 
    c. New applicants and summer residents who previously resided in other student housing cooperatives recognized by UCHA provided that they meet the academic status requirement and apply at least 60 days before the start of the appropriate quarter or summer session. 
    d. New applicants and summer residents who meet the academic status requirement.

2. A member may apply for payment extension from the Executive Director (ED). A payment extension may be obtained for 7 days only. An extension for a further 7 days may be obtained at the discretion of the ED. Members receiving payment extensions must pay their entire balance down to $0 by the extension due date. Failure to do so may result in the notification of a credit agency, loss of member privileges, and uncooperative fine, and/or expulsion (see Appendix). To qualify, the member must meet the following conditions:
   a. The member's current balance may not be delinquent (i.e., not more than $50 from the previous payment)
   b. The member may not be chore deficient for more than 3 chore and/or bathroom shifts.
   c. The member must have lived at UCHA during the entire previous two quarters, with summer counting as one quarter.
   d. The member may not have defaulted on any payment extension within the previous two quarters.
   e. The member must produce a verifiable means of income, such as:
      i. A check stub.
      ii. valid financial aid offer (FOR FIRST PAYMENT ONLY).
      iii. Any other suitable proof of financial means.
   f. The member may not be a RESIDENT (someone living at UCHA but not a member). (BoD 12/12/99)

1. Parking spaces are assigned based on seniority and restricted to the assignee and the vehicle the assignee has registered with the Co-op. 
   a. A copy of a current vehicle registration must be submitted to the office by the deadline set by MemCom in order to participate in bump. 
   b. Co-opers receiving parking through bump are granted tenure on that spot. Should the said member move out for or during the Summer and return in the Fall quarter, they will retain tenure on the same parking spot, so long as they meet the requirements to be deemed a member in good standing and notify by filling out the parking Bump form. 
   c. A copy of a current vehicle registration must be submitted to Facilities in order to receive a temporary parking spot. 
   d. Co-opers assigned a temporary parking space after bump will not receive tenure. Temporary parking spots remain in effect until the next bump. 
   e. In order to maintain tenure on a parking spot, a renewed/updated copy of the vehicle registration must be submitted to facilities by the vehicle registration expiration date. Failure to do this will result in the immediate loss of the parking spot. 
   f. Vehicles must be registered in the assignee’s name or in the name of their legal guardian. There are no exceptions to this rule. Members who lease, borrow or rent vehicles are not eligible to Bump for a Tenured parking spot. They may, however, obtain a temporary parking spot through the waitlist for periods in between the official Bump process. When the vehicle is listed in the name of a legal guardian, automobile insurance papers must also be submitted, in order to prove the relationship. 
   g. It is a co-oper’s responsibility to notify the Accounting Office and the Facilities Office if they change vehicles and to provide a new set of documents. Failure to do this will result in the immediate loss of the co-oper’s parking spot.

4. Leave of Absence
   a. A co-oper is excused from their chore obligations provided that they are physically away from UCHA continuously for at least 14 consecutive days and gives the office at least 48 hours written notice prior to departing. (BoD 9/9/96 “work” changed to “chore”). The maximum duration a member may be on an approved Leave of Absence is 21 days, after which time the member will receive a reduced chore debit equivalent to the prevailing credit rate for each week they are away from UCHA. In special circumstances the Leave of Absence may be extended beyond 21 days with the ED’s or BoD’s approval. Such an extension must be obtained prior to departure.
   b. A member is eligible to apply for a Leave of Absence from the chore requirement during the summer session and winter break periods only. At all other times during the year, a co-oper will be required to find a replacement or receive a fine at a reduced rate equivalent to a credit, if the member intends to be away and will be unable to attend their chore shift or find a replacement. Any exceptions will need to be approved by the Executive Director. A member must have lived at the UCHA a minimum of 70 days to be eligible to apply for a Leave of Absence request.
   c. To be eligible to apply for a Leave of Absence request, member must:
    “i. Have lived at the UCHA for a minimum of 70 days.
     ii. Have fewer than 20 hours of chore deficiency.
     iii. Have fewer than 5 bathroom deficiencies.
     iv. Have less than $400 in R&B delinquency.

1. Any member who misses more than 8 chore shift hours, or fails to pass or perform more than 2 bathroom clean-up shifts, will be immediately placed on probation and have their seniority reduced to zero. The member will immediately lose their parking spot (see also section VII.B.5), and will not be able to apply for parking until their probationary status is lifted. To be restored to full seniority (for the purposes of the following quarter’s Bump), any member on probation will have until the last day of the quarter to bring down their deficiencies to no more than 8 chore shift hours or 2 bathrooms clean-up shifts.

3. Any member deficient by 20 chore shift hours or 5 bathroom shifts will be summoned to a mandatory expulsion hearing with the Board of Directors. Unless the Board deems the circumstances for non-fulfillment are due to unavoidable circumstances, or unfamiliarity with the process due to being a first quarter member, the expulsion will be final. However, should the said member's appeal be accepted, and a make-up opportunity be given, such grace shall be given as a one-time opportunity only. Should the member be deficient again the following or at a subsequent quarter, no grace or leniency shall be afforded, and the said member shall be duly expelled.

1. 
   a. MemCom is responsible for conducting Bump each quarter. 
     i. The Membership Committee will be responsible for setting the bump dates for session 1 & session 2. 
     ii. MemCom will have general jurisdiction (not exclusive jurisdiction) over Bump, Parking, room tenure, seniority, room selection process, and room occupancy. 
     iii. Any dispute regarding seniority, the room selection process, or parking, may be referred to the Executive Director (by MemCom or a member) who will have a determining say in negotiating the settlement. Any decision of the Executive Director (ED) may be appealed to the Board of Directors to be heard by them no later than at their next immediate meeting. 
     iv. The ED or the BoD will be authorized to postpone or reschedule Bump in the event there are irregularities that preclude a fair process, or that the Bump schedule has not been adequately observed. 
     v. Quarterly Bump will be conducted in conjunction with the front and accounting offices. 
     vi. The ED shall have jurisdiction to set aside rooms from the process as deemed necessary. Any changes to this may be negotiated by MemCom with the ED. 
     vii. Bump will be carried out in accordance with the following (Bump) schedule: (The official Bump process will commence effective the week prior to the event ). 
         1. Friday: MemCom shall post notices on the doors of all R&B delinquent and chore deficient members. For the sole purposes of bump, R&B delinquency shall be defined as having a balance of $100 or more and chore deficiency shall be defined as owing the equivalent of $100 or more due to any chore missed, which includes bathroom fines, QPH fines, and chore fines, both with notice and with no notice. All chore fines must be worked off, and any money paid to reduce those fines will remain as credit on the co-opers’ account. 
         2. Saturday and Sunday (7:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m.): MemCom will be required to answer and guide members about the upcoming event. 
         3. Monday (9:00 p.m.): All Bump/Tenure requests to be turned in by the membership. Late Bump/Tenure forms will not be accepted. 
         4. Tuesday: MemCom will post a tentative listing of the Bump status of each member. 
         5. Wednesday: It will be mandatory for MemCom to conduct a final meeting for the benefit of all members who have questions, concerns about irregularities or have questions about their status at Bump. This will also be the Final opportunity for consideration of any changes/exceptions that MemCom might make. 
         6. Thursday: MemCom will turn in all information (i.e., Seniority lists, Tenure lists, Room-availability list) to the office for final verification on information. 
         7. Friday: Amended results (if any), to be handed over by the office to MemCom.
         8. Saturday: Bump (Room and Parking). 
         9. Sunday: MemCom will hold office hours (12pm-4pm), for members with (post-bump) related concerns. 
         10. Monday: MemCom will hand over a complete and updated list of the Bump results to the office. 
   b. Bump will be conducted in two sessions: 
     i. Session 1 will consist of the Bump (room/parking) bidding process. And session 2 will consist of the actual move-in process to be conducted the next day, from 10 a.m. to 9 p.m. 
   c. MemCom should take steps to ensure that members are made aware when their existing roommate applies for Bump. Members themselves are also responsible for communicating with their existing roommate their intention to Bump.

6. Members may, on request, and with approval from the facilities department manager, temporarily remove furniture items from their room. Policy details are specified in the official Furniture removal (FR) policy guidelines brochure. The deposit for removal of such is $100 and must be paid prior to removal of any furniture.

1. Academic status requirement: To meet the academic status requirement, a member must satisfy the conditions of this section or the following section (A.2). To maintain membership during the regular academic term, a member must be enrolled in a degree program (bachelors, Masters, PhD), or a professional degree program (law, medicine, etc.), at UCLA, fulfilling any one of the following requirements: 
    a. Meeting minimum progress requirements toward a degree, or professional degree. Minimum progress shall be defined as enrollment in, and the satisfactory completion of, the minimum number of units of each academic term: 12 quarterly units (12 semester units), for both undergraduate, graduate, and certificate program students. 
    b. Any student (graduate or undergraduate), in the last quarter or semester of a degree program may fall below the (above mentioned) unit requirement if the course work is all that is needed to graduate. Students enrolled in programs other than a Bachelors, Masters, doctorate or 1-year (minimum requirement) certificate program, will not be eligible for this privilege/concession. 
    c. Any graduate student who is on Filing Fee quarter and continues to work on a Master’s Thesis/dissertation, approved by UCLA, is also considered to be meeting the minimum academic status requirement. In such cases, satisfactory documentation from the institution granting the degree needs to be provided. 
    d. Undergraduate, graduate, PhD students, PhD holders of UCLA working on a temporary research project at UCLA. Full-time career researchers are not eligible for UCHA housing.
    e. Be a member of UCLA staff. UCLA staff shall be defined as a person in direct relation to the academic education of UCLA students (i.e., primary teacher in academic education, contributing 50% FTE hours or more per week to teaching duties). “Academic education” is defined as courses offered by the UCLA registrar.

5. A majority of the Association members voting in a regularly scheduled election may accept any rule changes not pertaining to the powers and jurisdiction of the Membership Committee (MemCom). All such measures to be considered in a regularly scheduled election shall be posted at least one week (7 days), in advance of the election. Any rule that would be changed by the measure shall be quoted in full. (BoD 5/25/99)

The BoD or MemCom may bar a member from attending their meetings in cases where the member has demonstrated a pattern of behavior that significantly disrupts, impedes, or detracts from the body’s ability to effectively run their meetings. This procedure requires a vote of both MemCom and the Board of Directors, and one body must approve the other’s ban in order for it to go into effect. The body banning the member from their meetings must pass the motion with 5 members voting in the affirmative and the other body approving their ban also with 5 members voting in the affirmative. Neither body can ban one of its own elected members from attending meetings during his or her elected term, except as specified in Robert’s Rules of Order. The ban shall be in effect for a period of one quarter. Banned members who violate this prohibition will be fined for uncooperative behavior and disregard for the ban on numerous occasions may be deemed uncooperative behavior. If the banned member is requested, or summoned, by the body in question to attend one of its meetings, then the ban will be considered to be temporarily suspended for that purpose. The ban can be rescinded by a majority vote.

3. Co-opers will be given 2 chances to meet the cleaning standards and pass a bathroom inspection: the first on the scheduled day, and the second on the following day.
   a. Co-opers who fail bathroom inspection will be given one bathroom chore failure and an “Inadequate Cleaning Fine” of $20 per shift (see also III.C.3.d).
   b. All bathroom cleaning chore failures must be made up by cleaning bathrooms. The number of bathrooms to be cleaned in a make-up shift will be equal to the number of bathrooms that should be cleaned in the shift that the member failed (see also III.C.3.d. and III.C.3.e.).
   c. Failure to adequately perform bathroom chores will result in loss of seniority or expulsion. See the following rules 5 & 6 for details.
   d. For purposes of determining expulsion and loss of seniority, a bathroom deficiency would be defined as a failure to clean bathroom(s) per hallway as per the sign-up requirement and not per individual bathroom. Members living in a given hallway have priority in sign-ups over those members living in other hallways.
   e. Bathroom deficiency make-ups will be defined as:
      i. A member living in a one-bathroom hallway must clean up one bathroom.
      ii. A member living in a two-bathroom hallway must clean up two bathrooms.

text: 2. Tenure is automatically granted to UCHA members residing in HHH triples and selected triples in Essene (see VI.D.3) through all quarters.

3. Selected rooms in Essene (in addition to triples in HHH) are to be set aside for automatic tenure. This is to minimize the crowd at Bump and to minimize the inconvenience to new members who do not wish to Bump. Approved (“Selected”) rooms: Essene S-1, S-2, S-3, S-4, S-13, S-14, S-15, S-16.

4. If MemCom grants tenure (room/parking) outside of the official Bump process, the decision will be considered tentative, until referred to the Board of Directors for final approval. This decision must be communicated to the Board by the MemCom chair or representative at the next immediate official board meeting. The Board must then, at the same meeting, by a majority vote, ratify or deny the tenure. Tenure granted without the approval of a majority of the Board will be void.

2. Prior to Bump, MemCom should post a room list showing tenured and non-tenured room designations. Co-opers who will participate in Bump must fill out and return an official Bump form to MemCom prior to the official deadline set by MemCom. Once a person submits a Bump form, they lose the tenure that they may have gained from a previous Bump. (2/3 Association vote, March 2001)

3.  Members participating in Bump may submit either an Individual Bump form or a Group Bump form. Groups may consist of two, three, or four people. Each group is assigned its own priority numbers. In the event that a Group is dissolved, the members involved participate under their individual priority numbers.

4. Groups may be dissolved during BUMP day if no available room can house all the members together, or if at any point during Bump all the members in the group agree in writing to dissolve the group. Prior to Bump day, the Membership Committee may allow groups to be dissolved without unanimous agreement of the group members if the decision is made by their last regular meeting before Bump.

5. MemCom will assign priority numbers to each Individual and Group participating in Bump. The priority number is based on the seniority of the individual or of the members of the group respectively. In the event that two or more groups have an equal number of days seniority, then the group having the lowest average deposit numbers will gain priority placement. Twenty-four hours before Bump, a list of all participants and their priority numbers will be posted, and each Individual or Group will be given notice of their priority number and the time at which they are to appear to choose a room.

6. Delinquent and/or deficient members requesting to participate in Bump will be assigned a priority number as if they had zero days of seniority. MemCom may permit a member to participate with their full seniority on the advice of the AMO or the ED.
7.  The seniority of a Group requesting a priority number is computed by the average seniority of all Group members multiplied by 1.5.

8. If a co-oper wishes to be tenured into a room already partially occupied by a tenured co-oper(s), a Tenure form must be filled out and turned in by the appropriate deadline as per the Bump schedule. This Tenure form is binding on all participants and the person being tenured loses any tenure on another room gained from a previous Bump. If a member wishes to be tenured to a room occupied by two persons (in the case of a triple), and 2 or 3 persons (in the case of the quad), then agreement must be reached between all roommates on who should be tenured in. In the instance where only 1 person has tenure on a triple or quad and multiple vacancies exists in the same room, the said member may grant multiple tenures, if they so wish.

9. At bump there shall be a board display of untenured and unfilled rooms, which will be updated every time a new room is chosen by an Individual or Group. Participants will be called to choose an open room in the order of their priority numbers.

10. Participants not arriving at the time for their turn will lose their priority position, but may choose a room when they finally do appear. Participants unable to attend Bump can choose a room by absentee request by giving MemCom the name of another co-oper who will have the authority to choose a room for the absentee’s turn. Any untenured co-opers, who do not request priority numbers will be assigned arbitrarily (aside from sex) by MemCom to the rooms left over.

11. To prevent males and females from being forced to move into rooms together near the end of Bump, the following rule will be enforced: when the number of room spaces left in rooms occupied by males equals the number of males left to choose rooms, males will no longer be allowed to bump into unoccupied (neutral) rooms. Similarly, when the number of room spaces left in rooms occupied by females equals the number of females left to choose rooms, females will not be permitted to bump into unoccupied (neutral) rooms.

12. No Group or Tenured Group may be composed of two males and one female or two females and one male, although Groups of one male and one female are permitted. The purpose of this rule is to prevent UCHA from being left with an empty space that might occur if one member of such a Group should move out leaving one male and one female remaining in a triple room. UCHA may be unable to fill such a space, even though a waiting list may exist, as UCHA may not force an individual to share a room with persons of the opposite sex without consent. However, MemCom may grant exceptions to this rule on a case-by-case basis provided that all parties involved agree voluntarily.
13. A returning member who fails to check-in by the deadline to turn in Bump/Tenure forms as posted by MemCom will not be eligible to participate in Bump or retain tenure on their previous room.

14. Any member who pays their delinquency down to qualify to Bump with full seniority status, will immediately lose Tenure on their room and be required to Bump with zero seniority at the next immediate Bump, if the payment is returned as not valid for insufficient funds by the bank. In addition, if such a member Tenured in a roommate, the roommate will also immediately lose Tenure on the room, and will be required to bump at the next quarter’s Bump. The member, who turned in the invalid payment, will not be eligible to be tenured into a room as well, at the next quarter’s Bump. The accounts department will issue a final statement 12 days prior to the Bump date which will be the determining statement for matters relating to rent delinquency.

15. The deadline to clear all monetary delinquencies will be 10 days prior to the official Bump day of that quarter. The deadline to clear all chore and/or bathroom deficiencies (for Bump purposes only), will be 7 days after the official check-out day of the previous quarter (example: 7 days after Winter Quarters official check-out day for Spring Quarters Bump).

16. Any member who loses their seniority will not be eligible to be tenured by another member and will be required to Bump with zero seniority. This member may not group bump with another member, thereby not being able to average their seniority. Members bumping with zero seniority because of rent delinquency or chore/bathroom deficiency will not be able to select doubles, suites, singles or parking spots until full seniority is restored. However, in the case of temporary assignments/transfers a member room and board delinquent, chore or bathroom deficient will not be eligible to transfer to a single, suite/double room or be eligible for a temporary parking spot, until their balance is brought down to $50 balance and/or zero chore/bathroom hours. Any exceptions to the requirements for mid-quarter room transfers will need the authorization of the Executive Director or the Membership Committee.
2. Co-opers who change rooms without the permission of MemCom or the Executive Director will be subject to disciplinary actions.

3. Members are expressly prohibited from doing the following without the approval of MemCom at its official meeting: 
   a. Tenuring a roommate and moving to a different room at anytime during that quarter. 
   b. Tenured to a room and switching to a different room at anytime during that quarter. 
   c. Tenuring a roommate and moving-out at anytime during that quarter.

4. Any member/s found in violation of Rules 2 and/or 3 of this section will receive a fine of $100 and automatically loose tenure on both rooms and in addition will be required to Bump with zero seniority at the following quarter’s Bump.

5. Any member changing rooms (except for the Bump process) without official authorization from the Executive Director or the Membership Committee will lose tenure on their room, and be forced to bump with zero seniority at the next immediate Bump. Such member will also receive a mandatory $100 penalty fee.

2. Members requiring room accommodations must have their accommodations met and arranged prior to their move-in date if possible. If members are already residing at the co-op when they request their accommodations, then their needs must be met as soon as possible.
3. Members who develop a disability during their stay at the co-op must have their accommodations met as soon as possible.

2. Cheating. Any co-oper who obtains, or lends, their parking spot to be used by another will incur the following mandatory punishments and a possible expulsion, if MemCom feels that expulsion is also warranted. Likewise, any co-oper who receives, or uses, such a spot will also incur these punishments. 
   a. A $250 uncooperative fine. 
   b. Loss of room tenure and a complete reduction of all seniority to zero. 
   c. Immediate loss of their parking spot and denial of future parking privileges.
3. Unauthorized vehicles, and vehicles not parked in their assigned spaces, may be towed.
4. The Office will periodically check parking spaces for compliance.

5 a. Any member with a R&B delinquency of $200 or more will automatically lose their parking privileges unless the outstanding balance is paid down to below $200 within 7 business days from when payment to UCHA was due. Furthermore, the member is restricted from applying for a temporary parking spot until their outstanding debts are paid off to zero. The Tenured spot may be regained during the following quarter’s Bump—that is, the quarter  immediately after the one in which the member has lost their parking privileges, assuming proper fulfillment of all eligibility requirements.

  b. Any member renting a UCHA parking space, with a chore deficiency of more than 8 hours, or fails to pass or perform more than 2  bathroom shifts will be immediately placed on probation, lose parking privileges, and have their seniority reduced to zero. Payment of the fines associated with missed chore and bathroom shifts is not a substitute for the obligation of making up the shift hours.  For the purposes of the following quarter’s Bump, the said member will have until the last day of the current quarter to bring down their deficiencies to no more than 8 chore shift hours and/or 2 bathrooms clean-up shifts, in order to be restored to good standing and be eligible to Bump with full seniority (at the following quarter’s Bump). The Tenured spot, may also be regained during this Bump—that is, the following quarter’s Bump, immediately after the quarter in which the member has lost their parking privileges, assuming proper fulfillment of all eligibility requirements. Members who have violated this rule and have thus lost their parking privileges  may apply for a spot on the parking waitlist upon reducing their chore/bathroom deficiencies to the aforementioned standard necessary to remain in good standing.
 
 c. Any member who does not meet the standards for membership/failed registration check will not be eligible for a parking spot at the UCHA and will lose their parking spot immediately. They will not be eligible for a UCHA parking spot until they pass registration check for full seniority to be restored for the following quarter’s Bump, and be eligible for parking privileges. The Tenured spot may be regained during the following quarter’s Bump—that is, the quarter  immediately after the one in which the member has lost their parking privileges, assuming proper fulfillment of all eligibility requirements.
6. Co-opers wishing to participate in parking bump, or receive a temporary parking spot, must read the UCHA VII.B Parking Rules and sign a statement they have done so.
2. If you are unable to attend dinner you may sign up for a late dinner prepared by food service staff before dinner begins. As soon as dinner begins the late dinner sign-up sheet will be removed.

3. Late dinners are available to those co-opers who have signed up on the late dinner list. Persons who have not reserved a late dinner by signing the list may not eat a late dinner. Violators will be charged the cost of the meal and may be fined (see Appendix).

4. You may not eat a meal and then sign up for that same meal to be taken out of the cafeteria or otherwise take from the premises that same meal. For example: you may not eat dinner and then also request the same late dinner (regardless if you sign up for it). Violation subject to an uncooperative fine (see Appendix). Sandwich materials available at breakfast are intended for people who cannot come back to the cafeteria for lunch. Again, violation subject to an uncooperative fine.

5. Persons in the dining room must be clothed in the manner prescribed by law. Persons in the dining room must wear a minimum of short pants or skirt, T-shirt or blouse, and footwear. Excessively grimy or dirty clothes may not be worn.
6. All co-opers must present the required identification by UCHA before eating a meal in the dining room.
7. Limits on food portions posted by the KC, AKCC, KCC, Cook or other authorized persons must be observed. There is a fine for violation, based on cost (see Appendix).

8. Kitchen and dining room equipment and non-disposable utensils (silverware, cups, plates, trays, bowls etc.) may not be removed from the kitchen or dining room, and violators may be fined (see Appendix).

2. If a host has not received written permission from the Office to have a guest eat a meal without the host, the host may be fined (see Appendix). The guest must present written permission to the Kitchen staff upon request prior to a meal. (BoD 7/16/97)
3. The BoD, ED, KCC or Cook may suspend the guest privilege or impose an upper limit on guests at a designated meal in order to prevent abuse of this privilege.
4. Any person who has checked out or moved out of UCHA owing money to UCHA may not be a guest for a meal.
5. Any non-member violating the guest or meal policy will be subject to a PNG hearing. Any member violating the guest or meal policy will be subject to an expulsion hearing.

2a. At least 24 hours advance notice must be given to occupants before room inspections unless an occupant is present and gives permission. However,  if credible evidence of danger to life, or to UCHA property exists, this requirement may be waived by the ED or the Security Crew Chief. The ED or the Security Crew Chief will report any such waivers and the surrounding circumstances at the subsequent Board meeting.

3. At least one occupant of each room or more than one inspector must be present during an inspection. However, if the room occupants have failed to respond to the advance 24 hours, ROM is allowed to access and inspect the room.

4.  The ROM crew may issue uncooperative fines in range from $ 35 to $200 [For fines above $100 dollars ED approval is required] pertaining to improper maintenance of a reasonable standard of cleanliness and upkeep. This includes possession of dangerous appliances, fire hazards, health hazards or other rule violations. The facilities manager, with the approval from the ED, may issue fines equivalent to  the value of property damaged and labor cost. These fines may exceed $200 dollars depending on the severity.

5. Hot plates or any other appliances containing heating elements are prohibited because of UCHA insurance liabilities. Non-compliance shall result in an uncooperative fine. Cooking of food in the cafeteria is permissible with a manager’s approval.
6. All occupants of a room are equally responsible for the condition of that room.
7. Any discrepancies in number or type of room furnishings upon checkout or room change are the responsibility of the room occupants, who will be charged accordingly.

8. Except in the case of emergencies, no one may enter a room without the permission of the occupants or 24 hours advance notice provided to occupants . However, exceptions may be made by the front office/ROM  in cases where a vacancy exists, and there is a need to inspect the room for the benefit of the incoming new member, 48 hours before their check-in date.

9. No one may move furniture from one room to another without permission from the ED or maintenance manager. Persons who violate this rule shall be charged a fee of up to $100.00 and shall return the furniture that has been moved or shall incur the cost of obtaining outside help. (BoD 09/07/00)
10. A co-oper may hold a meeting of a religious or political group in their room only with the unanimous consent of their assigned roommates.
11. Occupants of a room shall be responsible for leaving proportional space available for current and potential roommates. Failure to do so may result in a fine (see Appendix). (BoD 3/18/98)

12. All common areas, bathrooms, residence hallways, closets, and the HHH atrium shall be designated non-smoking areas. Failure to comply will result in an uncooperative fine and/or expulsion hearing. (BoD 5/10/01)

13. Usage of Air-conditioning units requires registration of the unit with the UCHA. Members may request authorization to utilize portable, non-window hanging air conditioning unit in their rooms. The facilities manager may approve the installation of window-mounted units on ground-level windows (such as a window facing a balcony). If approved by the office/facilities department, the registered owner of the unit will be required to pay a monthly fee of $50 to the UCHA. This fee will be levied between the months of April through October of each year, when anticipated usage will be highest. Members will also be required to make an additional payment of $50 for the installation or removal of the unit, should the installation require modifications to a window, which will be made by facilities only. To receive approval the air conditioning unit must be at or less than 10,000 BTU per hour/equivalent. No units requiring higher BTU will be approved. Any member installing an unauthorized air conditioning unit will receive a $100 penalty and summoned for an expulsion hearing. If a room is found to have an unregistered unit, members will be back-charged monthly payments from the beginning of the charging period (April).

2. A co-oper may have a guest sleep overnight for up to three nights per calendar month without charge provided that they have received the unanimous permission of their assigned roommates to do so and registered their guests with the front office. 
   a. A room guest staying in this manner does not have meal privileges except as a meal guest. 
   b. If a room guest stays for more than three nights the host may be fined up to $100, may be expelled, and will be charged for each night the guest stays after the third (see Appendix). 
   c. No person may be a room guest at UCHA for more than three nights per calendar month regardless of how many different hosts they may have. 
   d. No prospective resident may reside as a guest of the UCHA during the 7 days immediately preceding check-in

3. Hosts will remain with their guests during their stay at UCHA and will be responsible for their conduct. All unaccompanied non-members will be required to produce a valid ID (school/government), if/when requested by the Security Crew, Crew Chiefs and/or UCHA employees.

4. All guests must obey all rules covering the conduct of co-opers. Persons who have violated the rules of the Co-op may not be admitted as guests in the future. Any guest violating the rules of the Co-op will be required to leave immediately at the discretion of the ED. The host may appeal to MemCom, however, the decision of the ED is valid until the time MemCom makes a decision on the case. (BoD 09/07/00)
5. Hosts of guests may be fined for any fineable offenses committed by their guests.
6. A member may not be a guest for a period of up to 30 days after officially checking out of UCHA.
2. No smoking will be permitted in the kitchen and dining room areas. The BoD will designate other smoking/non-smoking areas.

3. Members are permitted to take cutlery, dishes or cups from the cafeteria with the following conditions:
   a. All cutlery, dishes, and cups are returned promptly to the racks in the cafeteria. Hoarding or improper disposal of these items is prohibited and may result in fines. 
   b. All cutlery, dishes, and cups are cleaned only in the dishwashing sink in the cafeteria and/or in the dishwashing machine in the kitchen. Dishwashing in bathrooms is prohibited and may result in fines.
2. Common rooms include but are not limited to: study rooms, TV rooms, and computer room.
3. Priority use of common areas is given to House, BoD or MemCom meetings or other official UCHA sponsored activities.

4. Priority use of common rooms (other than those defined in IX.D.3) is given for the designated purpose of the rooms. That is: 
   a. Computer room (Rm 623) prioritizes using computers or printing. 
   b. TV room 700 prioritizes using the TV. 
   c. TV room 723 prioritizes leisure activities, including but not limited to painting, origami, card/board games, and using the TV. 
   d. Study rooms prioritizes studying. 
   e. The Executive Director may at their discretion temporarily convert study rooms for other purposes (e.g., living spaces, offices, storage). Such conversions must be reviewed and approved at the next regularly scheduled BoD meeting, where the Executive Director shall report to the BoD on the rationale, purpose, and duration of said conversions. The BoD may, by a majority vote at a regular open meeting, temporarily or permanently convert or redesignate the study rooms in HHH for other purposes.
5. UCHA newspapers and periodicals may not be removed from the HHH common room and dining room areas. Violators may be fined (see Appendix).

2. UCHA facilities, limited to the Robison backyard, A-Wing lounge, triple H patio, lobby, atrium, and the OK room, may be used for private purposes, including parties and events, provided that: 
   a. Approval is obtained at least 72 hours in advance from the Membership Committee. Under exceptional circumstances the time requirement may be reduced at the discretion of the Membership Committee. 
   b. The name of the UCHA is not used unless the event is an official UCHA sponsored activity. (BoD 3/10/97) 
   c. The facility used is left remaining in good condition. (BoD 3/10/97) 
   d. There is no undue interference with house or co-oper activities. (BoD 3/10/97) 
   e. Members must sign a liability form saying that they hold UCHA free of liability and accept liability for any damages occurred during the duration of their even or party. 
   f. Any member who holds a party/event shall be required to deposit $50 in cash with the membership committee prior to the event. The money will be returned if there are no infractions of the Rules and the party venue is appropriately cleaned after the event. This includes keys being returned, bathrooms, and the general area being clean, and quiet hours being observed. 
   g. UCHA premises may not be used for large events or activities of more than 40 people that contain a majority non-members. Any exceptions must be authorized by the membership committee. In such cases a mandatory deposit of $250 will be required. 
   h. Sponsors of events are responsible for making sure that all bathrooms around the area that the event occurred will be cleaned no later than 2pm the following day. Failure to do so will result in a $25 fine per bathroom. 
   i. Sponsors will take charge of any unruly situation. They will be informed that UCHA will not be held liable for any accidents that occur during their event. Sponsors will be told that they will be held liable for any and all damages incurred to UCHA as a result of their event.
3. Persons attempting to use UCHA facilities for parties without permission or advance ED approval may be required to leave immediately. (BoD 9/9/96)

4. UCHA-owned tools, equipment or other supplies must be used on UCHA premises only. Permission to use such items must be obtained from the official or employee responsible for such tools, equipment or supplies.
5. Any co-oper using UCHA-owned tools or equipment is responsible for their loss or breakage.
6. UCHA premises may not be used for fundraising or similar activity by any member or non-member. Any member found to be in violation of such will be summoned for an expulsion hearing.
2. Persons smoking in those prohibited areas will be subject to a mandatory fine as per appendix B.

3. Persons who do not properly dispose of their cigarette butts will be subject to a minimum mandatory fine as per appendix B and must be summoned to MemCom for an expulsion hearing. This is a dangerous fire hazard and should be treated as such.
4. Smoking on the HHH patio will not be permitted. Any member found violating this rule is subject to a $35 uncooperative fine (Passed by majority membership/House vote – Fall 2013).

1. Posting or distributing flyers and notices is regulated by the communications policy. (See Guidelines) (BoD 12/5/00) 
   a. In the interest of constructive discussion that requires honesty, sincerity, and openness, co-opers must take responsibility for their own words. Anonymous postings will not be respected and will be taken down. 
   b. Libel is considered uncooperative behavior and will be fined. In serious cases, the offender may be expelled. 
   c. The BoD, MemCom, and the ED reserve the right to remove any postings from the Co-op, at their discretion.

2. An adequate official notice/summons shall be defined as a notice posted or delivered 48 hours in advance excluding the weekend defined as running from 5:00 p.m. Friday until 5:00 p.m. Sunday, legal holidays and inter-sessions. Co-opers are responsible for reading all notices on the official bulletin boards after posting and all official notices delivered to their message boxes or rooms.

3. Co-opers desiring to host a party with more than 15 participants on UCHA premises are required to complete the official Party Approval Form available at the Executive Director’s office. Co-opers who fail to submit the form, will be subject to a maximum fine of $100.00 and or expulsion.

4. Parties will only be open to co-opers and their guests; parties will not be advertised to the community at large. Any exceptions must be approved by the Executive Director. 5. Usage of the internal mailing system to send communications to the membership is limited to the ED, Department Heads, and Crew Chiefs, or a designated individual appointed by the aforementioned. Content of the communication must be pursuant to the scope of the department or crew’s immediate duties.

1. Forty-eight hours notice is required for any mandatory house meeting. This shall be posted on the official bulletin board. Any member who does not attend or does not give MemCom 24 hours notification of a reasonable excuse why they cannot attend is subject to a fine (see Appendix).

1. Quiet hours are times set aside during which loud or irritating noise, including that from electronic or stereo equipment or musical instruments, is restricted in order to allow for study and sleep. The noise policy of the UCHA is intended to facilitate an academic environment.

2. Quiet hours are set by the BoD and shall be posted conspicuously. 
   a. Quiet hours are in effect from: 
      i. Sunday 11:00 p.m. to Monday 10:00 a.m. 
      ii. Monday 11:00 p.m. to Tuesday 10:00 a.m. 
      ii. Tuesday 11:00 p.m. to Wednesday 10:00 a.m. 
      iv. Wednesday 11:00 p.m. to Thursday 10:00 a.m. 
      v. Thursday 11:00 p.m. to Friday 10:00 a.m. 
      vi. Saturday 2:00 a.m. to Saturday 10:00 a.m. 
      vii. Sunday 2:00 a.m. to Sunday 10:00 a.m. 
   b. Quiet hours must be observed all day (24 hours) during 10th week and Finals week of the UCLA academic calendar. 
   c. Exceptions may be made for official UCHA business and operations.

3. While the official quiet hours policy is as stated above, coopers are required to be respectful of other members and neighbors. 
   a. Unnecessarily loud or irritating noise is not permitted at any time. 
   b. Any noise deemed offensive to another member/neighbor would need to be curtailed immediately should an official complaint be made/received.
4. UCHA discourages the consumption of alcoholic beverages during quiet hours and alcohol (consumption) can be prohibited in all public spaces and common areas during quiet hours.

5. Enforcement: 
   a. Any officer of the BoD, MemCom, Security Crew on duty or the Executive Director can disperse any individual/group/groups in violation of quiet hours in common areas of UCHA. 
   b. Such a prohibition and/or dispersion is valid until the end of quiet hours for that day/night,and cannot be overturned. 
   c. Non-compliance will be deemed as uncooperative behavior, and will be grounds for issuing an uncooperative fine. Repeated non-compliance will be considered gross uncooperative behavior, and will result in a mandatory expulsion hearing. The disruptive member violating quiet hours may be fined up to $100.00.
6. Common areas are defined in IX.D.1.

1. Animals or pets of any type are not permitted on UCHA premises, except for Fish. Any exceptions to the above would require the express approval of the BoD or the Executive Director. Violators shall pay the cost for removal of the pet and any/all damage that may have been caused by the pet.
2. A fine may be given for leaving food or water on UCHA premises for stray animals (see Appendix).

3. Members seeking approval to have service an animal or emotional support animal in the room/UCHA, would need to submit the official application (available for this purpose on the official UCHA website) to the Executive Director for approval, at least 10 business days prior to arriving with the said animal.

1. Definition 
   a. Uncooperative behavior is any act or action caused by a member and sufficient enough to be deemed counter to the spirit and interest of the organization. 
   b. Such action must be considered egregious and cause feelings of hurt, shame or grief to another member or staff; or violation or disregard of a UCHA Rule or Policy or willful obstruction of its implementation. 
   c. Penalty for such may result in a fine of up to $35 (or as permitted by the rules of the Association) for each occurrence or infraction of the Rule or Policy, and in extreme cases such a member may be scheduled for an expulsion hearing (Passed by BoD 2/9/06 and approved with a majority vote by the House on 3/9/06).

2. Gross Uncooperative Behavior 
   a. The following acts are defined as gross uncooperative behavior: 
      i. Fighting, except that used to defend oneself against physical attack (BoD 6/3/98). 
      ii. Detonation of explosives, firecrackers or any incendiary device. 
      iii. Use of any type of firearm or projectile launching device. 
      iv. Throwing of objects from roofs, balconies, windows or other places that may cause injury or damage. (BoD 2/18/98) 
      v. Tampering with windows, fire alarms, or window safety devices, security devices, or any other UCHA property. 
      vi. Vandalism or destruction of property. 
      vii. Causing any obvious safety hazard to exist. 
      viii. Theft of UCHA property, the property of co-opers or of staff. 
      ix. Improper or fraudulent use of keys issued by UCHA. 
      x. Permitting any PNG to be present on UCHA premises. 
      xi. Physically endangering the life or limb of another human being on UCHA premises 
      in any way at any time. 
      xii. Excessively disruptive/unruly behavior regardless of substance or alcohol use/abuse. 
      xiii. Illegal or fraudulent use of internet facilities provided by the UCHA. 
   b. All of the above will result in expulsion from UCHA except in cases with extraordinary mitigating circumstances. The Membership Committee must explain these circumstances in their minutes in all such cases. Fines may be given as an additional punishment (See Appendix).

3. Any use of violence, except that used to defend oneself from physical attack by another person, shall constitute automatic expulsion from UCHA as well as a $100.00 fine. 
    a. Such expulsion shall occur, at the latest, by the beginning of the next UCLA intercession and may occur as soon as is allowable by state, county, or city law. Any member(s) being expelled for such actions is/are entitled to a formal hearing at a meeting of the Membership Committee prior to actual expulsion. Violence shall be defined as hitting, punching, slapping, kicking, hair pulling, or forceful shoving that causes a person to lose his or her balance. (BoD 2/21/95)

4. Possession of firearms or ammunition at UCHA is strictly forbidden. However, the BoD may grant exceptions for extraordinary case such as participation in sport activities requiring the ownership of firearms.

5. A co-oper may be fined or expelled for the violation of any rule, even though no specific penalty is mentioned. However, no single punitive fine shall exceed a maximum limit as specified in the Appendix or Rules.
6. Possession of illegal substances on UCHA property is gross uncooperative behavior. Members found to be in violation of this policy shall be subjected to an expulsion hearing.

7. Disrespect to any official (officials are herewith defined as members of the BoD, MemCom or Crew Chiefs or Staff i.e., Employees) of the UCHA will not be tolerated. Any member engaging in such will receive a fine of up to $100 and/or be subject to expulsion (or PNG’d in the case of non-members). 
   a. Disrespectful behavior verbal or written is defined as but not limited to: The use of racial, sexual or politically incorrect/insensitive slurs or name calling, physical or verbal threats, insults, and gestures, or actions that cause one to feel or appear humiliated or degraded.

1. Negligence is defined as destruction of property (personal or UCHA) or harm or potential harm to others caused by willful disregard of commonsense safety precautions. Any member found to be negligent (as defined above) will be subject to a $100 fine and may be summoned for an expulsion hearing by the Membership Committee.

1. Any co-oper who believes that a violation of cooperative living ideals has taken place can file a complaint with UCHA. Complaints shall be heard by the BoD, who will determine the actions to correct the complaints.

1. All work produced or modified for the UCHA (including, but not limited to: written documents, computer programs, drawings, designs, and systems) while serving the Co-op, shall be the property of the University Cooperative Housing Association (UCHA), and UCHA shall retain all rights.

1. Bicycles and Motorcycles not parked in designated parking areas may be confiscated. A note will be attached to the cycle informing the owner of this rule. If the cycle is not moved after a week Maintenance may remove it.
2. UCHA will not sponsor the purchase of alcohol at any time (BoD 11/05/03-amended BoD 12/03/03).
3. Skating, in-line skating, skateboarding, bicycling on UCHA premises is strictly forbidden. Any member found violating this policy will be levied a $100 fine.

4. Any member failing the quarterly registration check will immediately lose their parking privilege, not be eligible to run for elected office, and be subject to expulsion. Also, should the said member move out and seek re-admission to the UCHA, the said member will not be eligible for re-admission if they incur 3 or more fines for registration check failure/s.

5. All Co-op Surveillance equipment and footage is the sole property of the UCHA. Any person other than on duty security crew members, the security crew chief, the Membership Committee, Board of Directors, and the ED wishing to view any footage must receive prior approval of either the security crew chief, the BoD (by majority vote), the Membership Committee (by majority vote), or the ED. Furthermore, Any person other than the security crew chief, Membership Committee, Board of Directors, and the ED wishing to obtain a copy of any footage, must receive prior approval of either the security crew chief, the BoD (by majority vote), the Membership committee (by majority vote), or the ED. All footage requests that are fulfilled, regardless of whether the request is to view and/or obtain security footage, will be tracked by the security crew chief, detailing the person requesting the footage, the time and date at which the request was fulfilled, the purpose for the request, the authority which has endorsed the request (i.e. security crew chief, BoD, MemCom, ED), and the time, date, and location of the footage.” Upon request, these records must be made available to the BoD, MemCom, or the ED. In the case that the person requesting the footage wishes to distribute the footage, they must obtain the endorsement of two of the above four authorities listed above. Unauthorized access by any member will result in an uncooperative fine and summons for membership expulsion. Inadequate records keeping of footage fulfillments by the security crew chief may result in their removal from the position.

1. Members requiring disability accommodations of any kind for choreshifts can do so by providing doctor or school verification to AMO that states certain accommodations are necessary for their stay at the co-op.

2. Members requiring disability accommodations of any kind for room selection can do so by providing doctor or school verification to Mem-Com that states certain accommodations are necessary for their stay at the co-op.

1. Persons other than co-opers or staff of UCHA are defined as outsiders and shall not be permitted on UCHA premises without a host. Members are also advised to refrain from releasing personal information of other members to non-members without their written or verbal consent. Callous disregard of a member's right to privacy will be subject to an uncooperative fine.

2. Members of the staff, Security Crew on duty, Senior Member Leaders (SML), MemCom or the BoD may at any time require any outsider to immediately leave UCHA premises for any reasonable cause. If necessary, they may summon police assistance and cause arrest.

3. If at any time police are called to resolve a problem with outsiders, the person(s) responsible for summoning police help shall make a brief written report of the incident to the President of the BoD. This report shall be reviewed at the following BoD meeting.

1. Any person exhibiting disruptive behavior to UCHA, its staff or co-opers may be considered for PNG status. A person/persons declared PNG is/are prohibited from being present on UCHA premises at all times. The Board may however, at its discretion, specify terms and conditions such as time and/or location.
2. Any co-oper allowing the presence of a PNG on UCHA premises is subject to an uncooperative fine and a mandatory expulsion hearing (See Appendix).

1. Elections, except those where a majority of the MemCom is running for office, are under the exclusive jurisdiction of MemCom. MemCom members not running for election will serve as the election officers of that election.
2. If a majority of MemCom is running for office, the remaining MemCom members and Board directors who are not running for office will serve as the election officers of that election
3. Election officers are charged with organizing the election per the regulations set out in the by-laws and rules. Election officers may not be registration deficient.

4. A majority of election officers may appoint additional members who are not running for office to serve as election officers. A list of all election officers should be kept accessible and updated throughout the election process.
1. General elections are held on Tuesday and Wednesday of the seventh, eighth, or ninth week of each regular quarter.
2. Elections may not be held during Registration or Final Examination weeks.
3. Elections may not be held on legal holidays.
4. MemCom, when so ordered by the BoD, holds referenda and special elections. Elections may not be held during the summer quarter nor during any break between regular academic quarters.

5. Initiatives, recalls, and referenda are held within seven days after the BoD President receives a petition signed by at least 20% of the membership. Persons signing the petition must be UCHA members who are not registration deficient.
6. Runoff elections, when needed, are held on the Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday immediately following the balloting that results in no victor.
7. MemCom must officially notify the membership of an election at least 7 days prior to balloting.
8. Members’ R&B and/or chore deficiencies shall be posted 10 days before the first day of polling.
9. For the purpose of elections, R&B delinquency shall be defined as owing $100 or more.

1. Candidates must turn in an official Candidate Statement to MemCom, including a petition signed by at least ten members eligible to vote and sufficient proof of full-time student status no later than 7:00pm of the Saturday prior to polling in order to be listed on the ballot. MemCom shall post a list of candidates prior to voting time. Space shall be provided on the ballot for write-in candidates. Votes for write-in candidates shall be considered valid and shall count toward election of those candidates, unless the write-in candidate is not a UCHA member or is R&B/rent, chore, bathroom, or registration deficient.

2. Candidates must be UCHA members who fulfill the Academic status requirement as defined in II.A of the UCHA Rulebook, except when an exception to the aforementioned rules is obtained from the Board of Directors prior to the election. Candidates may not be R&B/rent, chore, bathroom, or registration deficient. Members on Grace quarters are not eligible to run for MemCom or BoD positions.
3. No member may run for more than one office in any given election.
4. Within seven days prior to the general election, a house meeting will be held. Each candidate will be introduced, be allowed to make a brief statement and answer questions from the membership.

5. Any elected official either on the BoD or MemCom is required to attend an orientation meeting to be held by the pertinent body upon their election. Upon adjournment of the meeting, the presiding officer shall certify, in writing, that they (the newly elected member) were in attendance for the length of the meeting. Incoming BoD members shall be required to read and sign the Board of Directors Code of Conduct. This is to ensure that any incoming members who may be elected to such positions will be aware of the nature of the responsibilities their new positions may carry. (BoD 5/22/18).

6. Any candidate holding a seat on either elected body (i.e., the Board or MemCom) who is running for a seat on the alternate body (i.e., the Board or MemCom) must vacate their seat in order to be eligible to run. Such a vacancy must then be filled by election the same quarter the seat was deemed vacant. The aforementioned candidates must turn in their candidate statements by 7:00 pm on the Thursday prior to polling in order to run in the election.
1.  Polling will be under the direction of election officers as defined in Rules XII.A.
2.  Candidates will be listed on the ballot in alphabetical order.
4. Ballots will be distributed to every member and their names will be recorded as they vote.
5. Absentee voters must obtain an absentee ballot from MemCom or the office.
6. The polls will be open at a minimum from 7:00 a.m. to 9:30 a.m. during breakfast and 5:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. during dinner and at maximum from 00:01 a.m to 23:59 p.m. on polling days.

7. All members except those who are registration deficient may vote. Members granted exceptions to Academic status requirement, as defined in II.A. of the UCHA Rulebook, may vote if the exceptions were granted prior to the start of polling.

8. No electioneering or campaigning will be allowed in the general polling area. The general polling area shall be defined by the election officers and official notice shall be given to the membership prior to voting. Candidates who violate this rule are subject to disqualification by the election officers. UCHA will reproduce each candidate’s candidate pitch to be posted in a campaign display in the polling area, to be maintained by the election officers.
1. After the polls close, ballots will be counted immediately by at least three election officers.

2. The position(s) will be filled (in order of decreasing term length) in decreasing order of votes received. If a tie exists, a run-off election must be held to determine term limits or fill the vacancy/vacancies. In cases where the number of votes polled between two candidates, that would determine the term limits or election of a candidate/s, is 5 or fewer votes, a recount must be conducted that same evening to confirm the term/winner.

4. Term limits are to be tabulated so that 2 one-year terms begin with the Fall Quarter, 3 one-year terms begin with the Winter Quarter, and 2 one-year terms begin with the Spring Quarter. A one-year term shall be defined as consisting of three regular quarters. Those elected in the general election of a given quarter will begin their terms in the following regular quarter so that those elected at the end of the Spring Quarter will begin their terms at the beginning of the following Fall Quarter. Serving during Summer does not count towards an elected member’s term limit.

5. Term limits should be tabulated from the longest to the shortest, so that the longest terms are filled in first, then shorter terms, and so on. This way, if not enough candidates are elected to fill the vacancies of a given body in an election, the one-year terms will be filled in first.

3. At least two copies of the election results with lengths of terms of those elected indicated would be signed by those who counted the ballots. One copy will be posted on the official bulletin board; the Secretary of the BoD will place the other in the official minutes. In addition to the election results posted on the official bulletin board, MemCom shall post the duration of the terms of those BoD and MemCom members who did not need to participate in the election. The terms shall be posted on the official bulletin board within two days of the final balloting and shall remain posted until after the next election.
4. MemCom's Vice-Chair will report on the results at the BoD meeting immediately following the elections.
3. To be deemed elected, a member running for BoD or MemCom must poll at least 20% of the total votes cast in that election.
1. Official UCHA Ballots, or balloting software approved by election officers, must be used for all elections.
2. All ballots must be marked clearly within the defined box for each candidate to be considered as valid.
3. Votes must be marked for no more than the number of candidates specified on the ballot, but may be for less than required.
4. In cases where a candidate receives multiple checks besides their name, that will be considered as one vote and not for the multiple amounts indicated.

5. A write-in ballot will be considered as valid only if 
   a) the person listed/written-in is a qualified member of the UCHA in good standing.
   b) at least the first/middle/last name and initials of the first/last name are clearly written in, and 
   c) polls at least 20% of the total votes cast in that election. 
If a qualified write-in fails to poll the minimum required votes, then any votes cast in their favor will not be considered as valid in that election. Invalidation of a write-in does not invalidate the entire ballot.

6. All votes must be counted in the front office or the A-Wing lounge of Robison and in the presence of at least one non-running Board member. No candidate may be present while ballots are being counted, until the official results are posted.

1. The Membership Committee (MemCom) is vested with general jurisdiction (“Exclusive jurisdiction” amended to “general jurisdiction” by House vote on 11/01/01), in the following matters: seniority, tenure, Room Selection Process and Room Bump, parking and exclusive jurisdiction over elections except elections where a majority of the Committee is running for office (See By-Laws VII.D). (BoD 9/9/96, “work” changed to “chore”).
2. The Membership Committee may consider for PNG status any member whom it has expelled.
3. MemCom will retain exclusive jurisdiction for R&B delinquency involving and including up to $400.00.
4. Once a member surpasses $400.00 in R&B delinquency, the ED, with authorization from the BoD, will take over jurisdiction of the R&B delinquent member’s account.
5. MemCom is vested with initial jurisdiction over fine appeals, chore assignment appeals, and all grace quarter cases. (BoD 9/9/96, “work” changed to “chore”).

6. A member may not present a case to MemCom a second time later than two weeks from the original decision. The said member may instead appeal the original decision (of MemCom) directly to the BoD, which must also be made no later than within two weeks of MemCom's original decision on the case. Any decision made by either body (to re-hear the case or deny the appeal), will be final.
7. MemCom decisions may be reviewed by the BoD only in circumstances specified by the rules.
8. MemCom members who are R&B delinquent may not vote on R&B delinquency related matters nor may any member vote on their own case.
9. MemCom has the authority to fine any member up to $100.00 for uncooperative behavior.
10. MemCom has the authority to issue uncooperative chore shifts (see Appendix) to any member for uncooperative behavior.

11. In cases involving claims of a violation of a member’s legal rights (federal/state law etc.), MemCom shall consult the Executive Director prior to making a decision on the matter and may elect to refer the matter entirely to the ED for a decision. The ED may at their discretion refer the matter back to the Membership Committee. In cases requiring expulsion MemCom must make the final decision.

12. In cases involving claims of harassment (including sexual harassment), MemCom may hear the case only after the complaint has first been lodged officially with the Executive Director, who will duly inform the Membership Committee and present the three parties concerned (i.e., MemCom, the petitioner, and the accused), with the documentation and guidance necessary for conducting the hearing in accordance with UCHA policies and procedures (BoD 2/27/2013, & approval of the of icial Complaint form, 3/06/2013).

13. The Chairperson of the Membership Committee may at their discretion be present (sit-in) at an executive session of the Board of Directors only in cases where the Board is hearing an appeal of MemCom's decision. If the chairperson cannot be present, they may appoint one of the committee members (i.e., MemCom) to attend the meeting/session.

1. MemCom is composed of seven UCHA members. Terms are for one year. Summer MemCom is composed of five members. Members who have served during the spring quarter and whose term continues through the fall quarter may, at their option, serve on the summer MemCom provided that they reside at UCHA.
2. Serving on MemCom satisfies weekly chore and quarterly project obligations. No member of MemCom may receive remuneration for work done pursuant to their MemCom duties. (BoD 12/12/99).

3. Vacancies on MemCom are filled by special appointment. In the event of the resignation or disqualification of a member on MemCom, their successor shall be appointed by a 2/3 majority of all the remaining members on MemCom within two weeks of the precipitating event. The term of the succeeding member is for the immediate academic quarter or summer only. The vacancy will then be filled in the general election. If the resigning member is still eligible for office and is still residing at UCHA, then the person shall continue to perform their duties until the successor is appointed, at which time that person is released from their duties.

4. MemCom assistants are non-voting aides to MemCom members. They are nominated by the MemCom and must be approved by a majority of those voting. The term of an assistant is one quarter or summer. (BoD 3/18/98).

1. MemCom is responsible for attempting to settle disputes between co-opers. It is empowered to order members to change rooms and grant and remove room tenure if necessary. The specific room change will be decided on after consultation with the ED.

1. The Chairperson of MemCom is responsible for setting the agenda, facilitating the meetings, and supervising those functions that involve all MemCom members. (2/3 membership vote, 11/99) In matters relating to the weekly chore or obligations of individual committee members, the chair shall be empowered to enforce compliance by issuance of a fine (up to $35 per week) or debit (up to 4 hours per week at the prevailing rate – see Appendix B), or compensation, by issuance of a credit, as deemed necessary. In all other matters, a majority consensus shall be sought and be the deciding factor.

2. MemCom members are responsible for all of the regular functions of MemCom which include “summonsing R&B delinquent co-opers to MemCom meetings, summonsing chore deficient co-opers to MemCom meetings, organizing and overseeing parking, and room bumps, upholding parking rules and regulations, conducting house meetings, and supervising elections and referenda. A MemCom member who is a candidate in an election may not work on that election. (2/3 Membership vote 11/99). The agenda of MemCom meetings must be posted with adequate of icial notice to inform the Membership.

3a. The MemCom is responsible for organizing the Parking Bump.

b. The Facilities Manager is generally responsible for upholding/enforcing parking rules and regulations.

4. In addition, MemCom shall appoint a Note taker from the general membership. The Note taker is not a member of MemCom. They are responsible for maintaining the minutes of MemCom meetings and for the public posting of the minutes within 48 hours of their approval by MemCom. (Passed 12 Feb 96 by the BoD)

5. At the end of each quarter, MemCom shall post in their minutes a summary of all the disbursements of their discretionary fund for that quarter and the Vice-Chairperson of MemCom will inform the Board about the disbursements of MemCom’s discretionary fund (which will be posted in the Board minutes).

6. Seats on the summer MemCom shall be filled in the following order: 
   a. Continuing committee members whose terms do not end until after the following quarter. 
   b. MemCom members elected in the recent spring quarter. Priority shall be given to the (elected) candidates/s with the highest number of votes received. 
   c. MemCom member/s whose program ends in the recent spring quarter and whose term continues into the next academic year may be appointed by a 2/3 majority of committee members either during the last meeting of the Spring Quarter or during the Summer Quarter. 
   d. Eligible members appointed by a 2/3 majority of committee members during the last meeting of the Spring Quarter. 
   e. Eligible members appointed by a 2/3 majority of MemCom during the Summer Quarter.

1. The Chairperson of MemCom will have the power to summon any co-oper to a MemCom meeting. MemCom must give a summoned co-oper adequate official notice. Anyone not able to appear must submit a note to MemCom before the meeting time or else they will be subject to a fine (see Appendix). MemCom may make decisions without the co-oper being present, provided adequate notice to appear was given.

2. Any MemCom vote is invalid without at least a simple majority of the voting members present voting in agreement. If a plurality of MemCom members abstains from the vote the matter shall remain unresolved.

3. The chair of MemCom may vote to make a tie or break a tie. The MemCom chair may vote to cause a 2/3 vote if the resulting vote would alter an outcome. The MemCom chair cannot vote twice (example: first to make a tie and then break the tie). The MemCom chair must be unbiased throughout the entire meeting until they decide to vote.

1. If a co-oper feels that they have been fined unjustly, they may appeal the fine to MemCom within two weeks after the fine is issued or at the next regularly scheduled MemCom meeting if no meeting is scheduled within the two-week period. (BoD 7/15/96)
tags: Fine and Uncooperative Chore Shift Appeals

text: 2. The co-oper must bring the fine slip to the MemCom meeting. (BoD 7/15/96)
tags: Fine and Uncooperative Chore Shift Appeals

text: 3. MemCom may not hear any fine appeal unless the person who gave the fine is given adequate official notice prior to the MemCom meeting. (BoD 7/15/96)
tags: Fine and Uncooperative Chore Shift Appeals

text: 4. MemCom may uphold, reduce or rescind a fine. (BoD 7/15/96)
tags: Fine and Uncooperative Chore Shift Appeals

text: 5. MemCom may not consider a fine given to one of its members. A member of MemCom must appeal their fine directly to the BoD.
tags: Fine and Uncooperative Chore Shift Appeals

text: 6. All of the above applies for uncooperative chore shift appeals.
