text: 1. Forty-eight hours notice is required for any mandatory house meeting. This shall be posted on the official bulletin board. Any member who does not attend or does not give MemCom 24 hours notification of a reasonable excuse why they cannot attend is subject to a fine. (See Appendix)
1. All MemCom Chairperson and Vice-Chairperson assignments are made by and from the MemCom. The term of each assignment is one quarter or summer.
2. MemCom shall appoint both the Chairperson and the Vice-Chairperson.

3. The Chairperson of MemCom shall be the chief supervisor of the Membership Committee; the Vice-Chairperson shall be the assistant chief supervisor and may preside over MemCom meetings. In matters relating to the weekly chore, obligations of the individual committee members, the chairperson shall be empowered to enforce compliance by issuance of a fine or compensation by issuance of a credit as deemed necessary. In all other matters, a majority consensus shall be sought and will be the deciding factor.
4. The Vice-Chairperson shall assume the duties of the Chairperson in the absence of the appointed Chairperson. The Vice-Chairperson shall be the designated liaison between the MemCom and the BoD.
1. The Board of Directors (BoD) is composed of seven UCHA members as stated in the UCHA By-Laws. During the summer, the BoD is composed of 5 UCHA members as stated in the By-Laws.

2. Terms 
   a. The term of office for the BoD is onr year, unless restricted by the By-Laws limit on summer Boards, number of directors or provisions of filling in vacancies as a result of resignation or disqualification. The BoD of any particular quarter and following quarter break (intercession) continues to hold office until the first meeting of BoD for the succeeding quarter. 
   b. An elected Director no longer meeting the academic criteria will be ineligible to remain on the Board. They will be eligible only after they meet the academic and UCHA criteria and are duly elected. Any academic eligibility change from UCLA to non-UCLA must be announced prior to the election for the next quarter, and they required to re-run for a non-UCLA position, if it is available. 
   c. No more than one non-UCLA student may serve on the Board at any given quarter. A non-UCLA student may serve on the Board only in the event they polled more votes than a UCLA student at an election. Any candidate elected or appointed to a seat on the UCHA Board of Directors must meet all eligibility requirements as detailed by the Rules of the Association at all times while in office.

3. Seats on the summer BoD shall be filled in the following order: 
   a. Continuing directors whose terms do not end until after the following quarter. 
   b. Directors elected in the recent spring quarter. Priority shall be given to the (elected) director/s with the highest number of votes received. 
   c. Director/s whose program ends in the recent spring quarter and whose term continues into the next academic year may be appointed by a 2/3 majority of the BoD either during the last meeting of the Spring Quarter or during the Summer Quarter. 
   d. Members appointed by a 2/3 majority of the BoD during the last meeting of the Spring Quarter. e. Members appointed by a 2/3 majority of the BoD during the Summer Quarter.

4. Vacancies on the BoD are filled by special appointment. In the event of the resignation or disqualification of a director on BoD, their successor shall be appointed by a 2/3 majority of all the remaining members on BoD within two weeks of the precipitating event. The term of the succeeding member is for the immediate academic quarter or summer session only. The vacancy will then be filled in the general election. If the resigning director is still eligible for office and is still residing at UCHA, then the person shall continue to perform their duties until the successor is appointed, at which time that person is released from their duties.

5. Up to 3 persons, who are not elected members, may be selected as honorary non-voting directors of the BoD. Honorary BoD directors are nominated by the BoD and must be approved by a majority of those voting. The term of an honorary BoD director is one year.
6. BoD assistants are non-voting aides to BoD directors. They are nominated by BoD and must be approved by a majority of those voting. The term of an assistant is one quarter or one summer.
1. Serving on the BoD satisfies weekly chore obligations.

2. No director of the BoD may receive compensation for work done pursuant to their duties. (BoD 05/22/01). All new appropriations that have not been budgeted for in excess of $5000 must be posted in the Agenda to be approved. However, in the case of emergency repairs, involving destruction to UCHA property, the requirement may be temporarily waived by the ED to authorize the allocation of funds needed to remedy the situation. The ED shall however, duly inform the Board of the details of expenditure.
3. A proposed consideration of a main motion must be posted in the Agenda of an open BoD meeting.
4. At least 4 directors of the BoD are needed (3 in the summer) to constitute a quorum for the transaction of any business unless more than 4 directors are required for specific cases.

5. Any BoD’s vote is invalid without at least a simple majority of those voting BoD directors present voting in agreement. If a plurality of BoD directors abstain from the vote, the matter shall remain unresolved.

6. The president of the BoD will have the power to summons any co-oper to attend a BoD meeting provided that adequate official notice is given to the summoned co-oper before the meeting. Any member who fails to show up for a summons by the Board of Directors will be levied an uncooperative fine of $10 per incident if no legitimate excuse for the absence is provided. The Board may only excuse the first absence without penalty.

7. The President of the BoD may vote to make a tie or break a tie. The President may vote cause a 2/3 vote if the resulting vote would alter an outcome. The President cannot vote twice (example: first to make a tie and then break the tie). The president must be unbiased throughout the entire meeting until they decide to vote.
8. BoD directors who are delinquent may not vote on delinquency-related matters.
9. BoD members may not serve as regular employees or stipended crew chiefs.
10. The lending of UCHA funds for a period of more than 2 weeks, other than as a payment extension, is not permitted under any circumstance.

11. Any audio/video still photography or electronic recording of the BoD as a whole or as individuals requires a unanimous consent of the Board. Any unauthorized electronic recording of the UCHA official is forbidden and may be subject to immediate expulsion.

12. The agenda of normal BoD meetings must be posted with adequate official notice to inform the Membership. The BoD may waive the adequate official notice only in an extreme emergency when a decision cannot be postponed. Regardless of circumstance, an agenda must be publicly posted in order for a meeting to occur. All items to be discussed at a formal meeting of the UCHA Board of Directors must first be approved at a prior committee meeting by a majority of the BoD. Additionally, items can be added at the joint discretion of the Executive Director and the BoD President. However, they may not delete any (agenda) items approved by the BoD at its prior committee meeting.
13. From time to time, the BoD may institute public water or energy conservation procedures violation of which, after a sufficient period of public notice, may result in a fine (See Appendix).
14. The BoD shall be vested with jurisdiction over chore deficiency.

15. Any long term project that significantly involves an employee’s resources and time would require the consent of the Executive Director. Any long term project that does not have the consent of the Executive Director requires the vote of at least five BoD members to be approved.
16. The Board must post in the minutes a summary of all the disbursements of the BoD discretionary fund at the end of each quarter.
17. In the absence of a functioning Membership Committee, the BoD may assume the relevant duties needing immediate attention.
18. The BoD has the authority to fine any member up to $100.00 for uncooperative behavior (BoD 5/13/2015).
19. The BoD has the authority to issue uncooperative chore shifts (see Appendix) to any member for uncooperative behavior.

20. The President of the BoD may at their discretion be present (sit-in), on any meeting or executive session of the Membership Committee. In their absence they may appoint another Board member to attend the meeting/session. The ED (Executive Director) may be present at any meeting or executive session of the Board of Directors or the Membership Committee.

21. All members of the BoD and MemCom shall have access to the Co-op’s internal IT system and members’ information pertaining to the members’ contact information, room number, rent, chore, and bathroom history. All members of the BoD and MemCom must receive permission through a vote of their respective body in order to share members’ personal records with those who have not been authorized with access to the Co-op’s internal IT system. Any previous member of BoD or MemCom who accesses the Co-op’s internal IT system will receive an uncooperative fine and summons for membership expulsion.
1. All officer and committee assignments are made by and from the BoD. The term of each assignment is one quarter or summer.

2. The BoD President shall act as a Chairperson of all official BoD meetings and as parliamentarian in addition to their duties as defined in the By-Laws. The President is also the chief supervisor of the BoD. In matters relating to the weekly chore or obligations of individual Board directors, the President shall be empowered to enforce compliance by issuance of a fine (up to $35 per week) or debit (up to 4 hours per week at the prevailing rate – see Appendix B), or compensation, by issuance of a credit, as deemed necessary. In all other matters, a majority consensus shall be sought and be the deciding factor.

3. The Vice President shall assume the duties of the President in their absence. The Vice President shall be the assistant chief supervisor of the BoD. In addition, the Vice President shall also be the designated liaison between MemCom and the BoD, and attend MemCom meetings. Their duties also include ensuring the effective operation of the board, training board members as necessary, and acting as a liaison with committee chairs. Their duties include special objects and activities, community service activities, and member education.

4. The Secretary shall act as defined in the By-Laws. As Secretary, they are responsible for the maintenance of the official files, including the minutes of the BoD and MemCom meetings, and the results of all elections and referenda. They ares also responsible for seeing that copies of the UCHA Guidelines, Rules, By-Laws, and Articles of Incorporation are kept up to date. (BoD 3/10/97)
5. The Treasurer shall act as defined in the By-Laws. In particular, the Treasurer shall make a financial report at each meeting of the BoD. (BoD 3/10/97)

6. In addition, there shall be up to 3 at large BoD directors during the regular academic quarters and up to 1 during the summer quarter. The at-large directors may be assigned special projects on a quarterly basis as approved by a quorum.
1. The BoD has the power to issue and enforce directives to employees, crew chiefs and other members.
2. BoD directives must be reviewed at the next regular meeting of the BoD.
3. Non-compliance with BoD directives may result in a fine, if applicable, or an uncooperative chore shift, at the next BoD meeting (see Appendix).
4. All BoD directives must be consistent with established standard BoD policy and the UCHA Rules and By-Laws.

1. The UCHA Board of Directors may by majority vote opt to rehear a case already decided by MemCom if it is deemed that MemCom’s handling of it is inconsistent with the Rules and By-Laws of the UCHA. In addition, the UCHA Board of Directors may opt to rehear a case already decided by MemCom by a 2/3 majority vote.
tags: Appeals to the BoD of MemCom Decisions

text: 2. In the event the BoD calls for a re-hearing of the Membership Committee (i.e., of their decision to expel a member), it may, at its discretion, also suspend the days allotted for the expelled member to move out, until a final decision is made on the matter (i.e., expulsion). Such a hearing must be held no later than at the next meeting of the Membership Committee.
tags: Appeals to the BoD of MemCom Decisions

text: 1. The UCHA BoD may by a 2/3 majority vote opt to rehear a case already decided by the BoD, if substantial new evidence relevant to the case, is presented. Such a case must be appealed within 30 days of the date of the Board’s previous decision. If no new evidence is presented and accepted as substantial by a 2/3 majority of BoD members, then the existing decision will remain as final.
tags: Appeals to the BoD of BoD Decisions

text: 1. The initiative process, as outlined in the by-laws, provides a method for the general membership to effect changes in the rules and/or operating procedures of the UCHA.

2. Any proposed change to the UCHA Rules and/or or operating procedures must be consistent with the by-laws. Proposals that in effect change, subvert, or provide alternate methods to powers and operating procedures as defined in the by-laws are not consistent with them.
3. Members may also propose changes to the rules and/or operating procedures of the UCHA directly to the Board of Directors at any of its regular meetings.

1. A petition is a formal proposal to change the rules and/or operating procedures of the UCHA. For a petition to be accepted and put up for vote by the general membership, it must be presented to the President of the Board of Directors by its original petitioner(s) at its regular meeting with valid signatures of support from at least 20% of the membership.

2. A petition should clearly outline its overall basis, scope and intent. It should address issues of process, feasibility, authority, enforcement/implementation and accountability/oversight, as applicable to the issue at hand. The petition must also include the specific verbiage to be used on the ballot itself.

3. Before a member petitions the membership for signatures, they must fulfill the criteria specified in B.2, and following which, submit their petition to the Board of Directors in full, including a signed list of all members who have helped draft the written petition (these members will be called the petitioners). The Board will then determine within 7 days if the proposed petition is in line with the by-laws and fulfill the requirements described in the UCHA Rules. If the proposed petition is judged to be in order, the Board will direct the office to make a copy with the attached signature form available to the petitioners within 48 hours. If there is disagreement on the interpretation of the by-laws, the Board must seek and follow legal counsel, whose opinion shall settle the dispute.

4. Upon the formal presentation of a petition to the President of the Board of Directors with valid signatures from 20% of the membership, the President will call a meeting of the Association (House Meeting) within 7 days. The President may, at their discretion, make the meeting mandatory for the membership to attend.

1. The exact wording of the signature form shall be set by the Board of Directors and must consist of an acknowledgement of the signee that they have read the petition, that they were not coerced into signing it, and they are signing out of the sincere belief that it is in the best interest of the association.
2. Only a registered petitioner may request a signature from the membership.
3. Using signature forms other than the ones provided by the office or modifying the forms provided will cause the petition to be invalid.

4. The proposed measure should be publicly posted in the HHH bulletin Board announcing the measure and pertinent details including as specified in B. 1. The posting should also include the opposing viewpoints to enable the membership to be abreast of both arguments (i.e. for and against).

5. A signature is only valid if at the time when the President of the Board of Directors receives the signatures, the signee is a member who is not registration deficient. The president may confirm with the signee that they did in fact sign the petition and that the signature is not forged.
1. The president must call a meeting of the association upon receipt of a petition. It is within the president’s powers to make attendance to this meeting mandatory for all members.
2. There must be adequate official notice for any such meeting to be publicly posted in the HHH lobby.

3. The sole purpose of this meeting is to discuss the proposed issue. This is not a regular meeting and as such members may not introduce new measures. The only new measure that may be discussed is the proposed issue. No vote during this meeting is binding.

4. MemCom shall chair this meeting. It must allow members from the Board of Directors and the Petitioners to both make a general statement and field questions. Opposing sides (if different from the Board), must also be given an opportunity for statements and Q&A thereby providing for a full discussion on the pros and cons of a measure.

1. The polling of the proposal is under the direction of MemCom, who shall conduct a secret ballot. MemCom will assign polling officers, primarily from MemCom, but may choose members outside of MemCom if needed to ensure the polling is neutral and secret. It will assign one polling officer to act as lead polling officer.
2. No Petitioner or Signee of the petition can be a polling officer.
3. No member of the Board of Directors can be a polling officer.
4. Polling officers are forbidden to attempt to sway the vote one way or another and in so doing, will be grounds for the negation of the vote.
5. Polling will take place over two consecutive weekdays and will be held from 7-9:30am during breakfast and from 5-7pm during dinner.
6. Polling may not be held on legal holidays or the day preceding legal holidays.
7. All regular rules regarding polling, as laid out in Chapter XII of the UCHA Rules, apply to the initiative.

8. MemCom will give the Board of Directors, any interested members opposed to the initiative, and the Petitioners the opportunity to supply a written statement of 200 words or less which will be made clearly visible at the polling area without one being more obviously visible than the other. Both statements must have the same font size and style.
1. MemCom will give both the Board of Directors and the Petitioners the opportunity to supply a written statement of 50 words or less to be printed side by side on the ballot.
1. To be declared passed, the initiative must fulfill the majority requirements as defined in the by-laws.

2. Once the results have been tallied, the result must be signed off by the lead polling officer who will then inform MemCom. MemCom will then announce the result of the ballot only after they have confirmed the ballot was conducted to the standards set forth in these rules.

1. The functions of UCHA Committees are as follows: 
    a. Conducting investigations and research into potential policies, reforms, or projects 
   b. Updating the Board about relevant developments in UCHA 
   c. Advising the Board on relevant business 
   d. Acting as liaison between the Board and various bodies of UCHA 
   e. Promoting member engagement throughout UCHA
2. UCHA Committees shall not have executive authority nor managerial roles over the day-to-day operations of UCHA.

1. Standing Committees of UCHA are Committees that are continuously operational. They are tasked with long-term policy development and project design to make improvements throughout UCHA. Standing Committees of UCHA are expected to regularly report their activities to the Board and ask for guidance when needed.
2. Select Committees of UCHA are Committees that are temporarily established at the Board’s discretion to manage short-term projects.
1. Committee Charters are legal documents that establish the existence of UCHA Committees as official bodies of UCHA.
2. Committee Charters outline the goals, responsibilities, functions, and frequency of meetings of each UCHA Committee that they establish.
3. Changes and amendments to Committee Charters must be approved by a majority vote of the Board at a public meeting.
4. Committees can be disbanded by an official dissolution of the Charter which requires a majority vote of the Board at a public meeting.

1. Chairs are Members of UCHA Committees with special responsibilities. Committee Chairs are the leaders of each Committee, and shall be appointed and dismissed directly by the Board unless otherwise stated in the Committee Charter.
2. Committee Chairs are responsible for organizing and running Committee meetings. They shall delegate tasks to Committee Members in order to fulfill the goals of the Committee Charter.
3. Committee Chairs shall certify whether a Committee Member has completed any or all of their Quarterly Project Hours at the end of the quarter.

4. If the Board deems it necessary, serving as a Committee Chair may fulfill a member’s Chore and Quarterly Project obligations until the Board explicitly revokes this privilege. 
   a. When a Chair fulfills their chore obligations by serving as a Committee Chair, they must record and submit minutes and action items from each Committee meeting to the UCHA Secretary within 72 hours. They must also report to the Board whenever the Board adds time to their agenda for Committee reports. 
   b. Failure to perform any of the requirements specified in XVI.D.4.a shall result in a one hour debit issued to the Committee Chair. 
   c. When a Chair fulfills their chore obligations by serving as a Committee Chair, they must organize and host the minimum frequency of meetings required by their Committee’s Charter. Failure to hold the minimum number of required meetings throughout a quarter shall result in a full week’s chore debit issued to the Committee Chair for every meeting missed. Committee Chairs may apply to the Board for a quarterly exemption from this requirement.

1. UCHA Committee Members shall work under the direction of the Committee Chair. Committee Members shall be appointed and dismissed by the Committee Chair unless otherwise stated in the Committee Charter.
2. If certified by the Committee Chair, serving as a Member of a UCHA Committee shall satisfy part or all of the Quarterly Project obligations of the Member.
3. If the Board deems it necessary, serving as a Committee Member may fulfill a member’s Chore obligations until the Board explicitly revokes this privilege.
4. Committee members should always provide sensitive information to the Board to consider before disseminating it to the membership or third parties.
1. As UCHA Committees are committees of the UCHA Board of Directors, each member of the various committees retain the relevant fiduciary obligations that are held by the Directors of UCHA.
tags: Fiduciary Obligations of UCHA Committee Members

text: 2. Fiduciary obligations of UCHA Committee Members include but are not limited to acting in good faith while taking action on behalf of or representing UCHA, never acting negligently regarding official business of UCHA, and following and upholding the mandates of their Committee’s Charter.
tags: Fiduciary Obligations of UCHA Committee Members

text: 3. Fiduciary obligations particularly emphasize sound financial decision making. Whenever a Committee Member is in the position to either allocate UCHA funds or substantially advise the UCHA Board on allocating funds, they must do so in ways that they believe is in the best interest of the association after thorough investigation.
tags: Fiduciary Obligations of UCHA Committee Members

text: 4. Any Committee Member who is found to have violated their fiduciary obligations shall be dismissed from Committee service.
tags: Fiduciary Obligations of UCHA Committee Members

22. All members of the BoD shall have access to BoD accounts. All members of the BoD must receive permission through a vote of the BoD in order to share the contents of BoD accounts with those who have not been authorized with access. Any previous member of the BoD who accesses the accounts will receive an uncooperative fine and be summoned for membership expulsion. The login credentials of the BoD accounts shall be changed at the end of every Quarter.

9. Apart from Bump and aside from exceptions , ROM will be solely responsible for room assignments to incoming members based on the vacancies present in the coop. Exceptions can include among others medical accommodations.
10. The only allowed form of contact is via email. Any other form of negative interaction will be considered retaliation and be subject to summons from Memcom/BoD.

14.The Membership Committee shall appoint a Secretary. As Secretary, they are responsible for the maintenance of the official files. They are responsible for writing the MemCom agendas, and in the absence
of a notetaker, performing the duties of notetaker.
